title: Moles
author: Camille Peri

content: If you had skin moles before pregnancy , they may get bigger or darker while you're pregnant. This most likely happens on your face, nipples, armpits, thighs, and vaginal area. You may also notice new moles. Doctors think your changing hormones cause these moles. Usually, new moles that appear during pregnancy are harmless. They often go away after your baby is born.

content_blocks.text: If you had skin moles before pregnancy , they may get bigger or darker while you're pregnant. This most likely happens on your face, nipples, armpits, thighs, and vaginal area. You may also notice new moles. Doctors think your changing hormones cause these moles. Usually, new moles that appear during pregnancy are harmless. They often go away after your baby is born.

sections.heading: Call Doctor If:
bullets: One of your moles changes, bleeds, or increases in size. Your doctor should rule out skin cancer, even though it's unlikely.

items: One of your moles changes, bleeds, or increases in size. Your doctor should rule out skin cancer, even though it's unlikely.

sections.heading: Step-by-Step Care:
bullets: Regularly examine your skin for changes.
Tell your obstetrician if you have a family history of melanoma or atypical moles.
Get regular skin exams by a dermatologist during your pregnancy if you are at high risk for melanoma .

items: Regularly examine your skin for changes.

sources: American Academy of Dermatology: "Common Pigment Changes."
European Academy of Dermatology and Venereology: "Moles and Malignant Melanoma Patient Information Leaflet."
University of Iowa Healthcare: "Skin Conditions During Pregnancy."
meta_description: WebMD explains how pregnancy affects skin moles.
